content: @Jack Huey we were going to do a planning meeting tomorrow, right?
Yes
Hey @WG-traits!
Hey folks!
How's everyone doing?
still…so…early
Ugh @Michael Goulet (compiler-errors) I sympathize :(
there's no :sleeping-cap: emoji
I've been up since 4:30 preparing my rust-verify 2022 talk
nothing like last minute
When is that?
Sunday
https://sites.google.com/view/rustverify2022/home
I think the talks will be recorded and made available
ooh
that's a fun idea for a deep dive
a "post rustvery2022 debrief"
https://nikomatsakis.github.io/rustverify2022/#1 <-- my talk, if you're curious
still very wip :)
Especially if there are any useful insights or comments
ps, I was talking to @Josh Triplett about the scope of this team
and he started to understand that I did consider operational semantics in scope
and kind of inseparable from type system
(what does it mean to talk about soundness if you can't talk about what the code does?)
and he was like "then why are you calling it the types team?"
heh
:upside_down:
:scream:
bike sheds
:bike::house:
he did have a suggestion I liked
"formality team" -- with the logo Ferrous in a tuxedo
the last part is the novel addition that I'm very into
hehe
I have a graphic designer I've been working with, may ask her to whip that up :)
Is that your daughter?
lol
:wink:
she's my secret weapon
gotta soften up the audience
anyway
re. types team
I sent a few messages regarding the RFC
of some additions
I know, I've been wanting to follow up on those
although if you want to edit that's fine with me, too
sure I can do that
so I think that the plan for these planning meetings was to schedule deep dives and do some status updates
do we have an "expected date" to open the RFC?
I was thinking I'd like to do that this month
yes
I honestly don't see anything other than the couple comments I made blocking just opening the RFC
Maybe Monday?
By the way, when is the deep dive today?
It's not like the RFC texts don't get edited
@pnkfelix 10 minutes ago
not deep dive, just planning :)
As in, this is the deep dive? Ah okay.
deep diving into logistics…
I am now realizing that the announcement was “deep dive planning”, not “deep dive / planning”

Jack Huey said:

Maybe Monday?

true
ok, let's shoot for end of next week
or sometime next week anyway
I'm going to submit a request for that logo ASAP!!
I also do propose formality team as the name
it suggests (which I kind of like) that the formality family of repos are owned by the team, also
the only downside is that it doesn't suggest that the team owns the implementation work
but then again, maybe that should stay the purview of the compiler team in a technical sense, I don't know, I don't care that much :)
I figure that line is slippery regardless
"types and formality team"
I honestly prefer types team
If nothing else, but for subjective reasons
Easy to say, remember, easy to associate with what we actually work on

Jack Huey said:

I honestly prefer types team

it's true
either way we are having ferrous in a tuxedo
I actually prefer it too :)
(in that sense)
Oh, definitely :)
well, let's not worry about that particular bikeshed just now
anyways

nikomatsakis said:

either way we are having ferrous in a tuxedo

(I already emailed the graphic designer :)
let's not bikeshed here
Before we go into deep dive topics
Any other announcements?
(actually, maybe it makes sense to do status updates first, then deep dive planning)
I was wondering if we wanted to do any status updates
yes, that
I think in the future I'd like to kind of prepare them so we have something to read
but that may not be realistic :)
I can give a brief update on a-mir-formality
since our last meeting, I've been refactoring it in various ways
for example, I separated out the "logic layer", which now knows nothing about Rust at all
and I'm working on defining subtyping
also @pierwill has been doing awesome work on documenting things
they started an mdbook
we didn't put up a github pages yet though
what I haven't done, but want to
is to kind of draft out a roadmap and some ideas for other people to look at it

nikomatsakis said:

also pierwill has been doing awesome work on documenting things

I saw that; quite exciting
though @lcnr and I were talking about modeling const generics

I'm not sure it's quite at the point where it makes sense to have lots of collaboration, though it maybe does. I am trying to decide what that point is. It could be a useful deep dive to have me draft up a kind of roadmap and we can discuss it.
it seems like it'd be nice to have an end-to-end of some simple MIR function (e.g., subtyping, perhaps not borrow checking)
I think that might be helpful in a couple months
so after this talk that's probably what I will focus on
given we have a number of other things to discuss :)

Jack Huey said:

I think that might me helpful in a couple months

s/me/be?

that was another thing I was thinking about -- what are places where it would be helpful to be able to model them precisely? const generics is one, it's an upcoming feature; associated types and WF bounds are another, that's a current problem.
if people have other thoughts I'd like to hear them, I had some notes on this but I forgot
anyway, that's all I got
Yeah, I think a rough roadmap/list of things to do would be helpful
If nothing else, but to solicit feedback on things missed
or to prioritize
I can give a brief update on GATs
So, the current "plan" is to propose and stabilize this next cycle
assuming all goes well
I am (slowly) writing up a "shiny future with GATs" blog post
That essentially tries to imagine a future where with have a GATified Iterator and such
but also other pretty things like Trait<Assoc<'_> = ...> syntax
I've also started a stabilization writeup, but that's on the backburner
We just landed a generic_associated_types_extended feature gate
Which will essentially be a playground for new GAT things
Right now, the only thing it does is ignore associated type bounds that reference HRTBs
But I have a PR that I need to rebase that allows object-safe GATs (at least in writing, not sure if they're usable)
We (Niko) need to also go through all the open issues one more time and give it a checkmark
I think that's about it
I'm excited to hear GAT stabilization is coming soon!
Me too :)
But, need to tick all the boxes first

nikomatsakis said:

that was another thing I was thinking about -- what are places where it would be helpful to be able to model them precisely? const generics is one, it's an upcoming feature; associated types and WF bounds are another, that's a current problem.

just had an idea here -- @Santiago Pastorino and I have been working towards stabilizing negative impls. This might be a good thing to focus on, figuring out what it would take to talk about them in formality too (and coherence).

PS @lcnr we should talk about the auto traits interactions with negative impls to make sure we got a good plan there and I'm not overlooking/forgetting things. I remember you were looking at that.
(that is, I suppose, another thing that he or I could give an update on)
would be interested in looking over negative impls wrt auto traits (and just in general)

The brief update there is that @Santiago Pastorino has been working to integrate negative impls with coherence and fix various bugs. This adds some rules for the compiler to determine when an impl cannot possibly overlap based on a negative impl (e.g., if you have impl !Debug for Foo then Foo cannot overlap with a T: Debug parameter).
We just setup a project board of the items blocking stabilization
one of them is to author an RFC :)
I think modeling in formality would be great, would let us be quite precise in terms of how it works
Is stabilization for that "too soon"?
I mean... don't expect it in the next couple of weeks :) technically we're still in the exploration phase
mmm okay
that said (famous last words), I feel pretty good about the changes
the initial formulation was messy but the one we landed on is nice and clean
one open question I am interested in:
we might be able to remove the idea of "fundamental traits" using this
that will take some experimentation on crater to determine, though
see also https://github.com/rust-lang/negative-impls-initiative/issues/3
(small announcement, just made an issue template for deep dive proposals: https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-traits/blob/master/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/deep_dive_proposal.md)
cool :)
any other updates?
@lcnr i'd be curious to hear a bit more about what you've been up to
maybe lazy TAITs? (@oli?)
I know that PR just landed
And already saw a bug report
there is no :sigh: emoji, is there
:pensive:

nikomatsakis said:

lcnr i'd be curious to hear a bit more about what you've been up to

looked into rewriting dropck, noticed that we use FnCtxt in weird ways, looked more into that, going to wait with anything big here until we can rip out the lexical lifetime stuff
that's an interesting question---
is somebody working actively on that?
Yeah, we should review NLL things sometime
@nikomatsakis you made a comment sometime that switching to NLL was blocked on leak check things
I think @Aaron Hill is most interested in pushing NLL
I can talk about lazy tait next steps, for anything else we need a deep dive :grinning:
side note that I am somewhat of the opinion we may be able to move region checking back into the original type check
but that's another story
re: leak check, I see, I'll have to refresh my memory to see if anything has changed since I said that
I say we do 5 more minutes of updates then schedule deep dive?
yes
I would really like to push on cleanup up region check and would be available to invest some noticeable amount of time into that
though I would need some pointers on what are our goals there n stuff
Maybe @oli is writing lazy tait next steps. If there aren't any other updates, we can start scheduling?
this is not quite an update, and I hate to be annoying about this, but I'd like to bring up chalk#754 again :sweat_smile:
I will see if I can knock that off today
I was going to separate out the SLG changes

so... there are some divergences between type-alias-impl-trait and return-position-impl-trait. I implemented type-alias-impl-trait conservatively so we can make it more like return-position-impl-trait later, but we should probably make sure that my reasoning is correct before stabilization.

there are some soundness bugs that I need to close, but I already fixed 2/3 and the third one is easy.

One return-position-impl-trait regression that crater missed needs to be fixed, too. It's just an overeager check causing an ICE, easy to fix.

So the main thing before stabilization is finishing up the rustc-guide and language-ref documentation and we should be able to send it off to the lang team for consideration
:tada::tada:
very cool stuff
Okay, so we currently have 5 open deep dive proposals: https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-traits/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Adeep-dive-proposal
And 4(!) Fridays this month to deep dive
8th, 15th, 22nd, 29th
i guess types team RFC first?
not sure I can do the 22nd, the rest wfm
debatable if we need a deep dive on that
if we need a sync meeting for that, might be fine without it
I'll be jetlaggedon the 8th though
Oh, I was actually going to propose we didn't do that
(the RFC)

nikomatsakis said:

I'll be jetlaggedon the 8th though

(which is neither here nor there really)
I put it on as an idea, but I'm not sure we really need it
happy to close :)
I think we probably do the subtyping and variance chapter review sooner rather than later
since that PR has been open for a bit
that's a good one for next weekI think
Yeah, also helps a jetlagged Niko
then lazy TAITs, chalkify, plt redex?

wfm-- though I just opened https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-traits/issues/39:

formality subtyping rules #39
I guess if oli is the only one with conflicts, they can decide which of chalkify or plt they would prefer
replacing plt redex with wg-traits#39 might be good, and maybe do the plt redex thing out of band?
or maybe even merge them :)
sounds good
not sure if that makes sense, maybe that's too much complexity
@oli any thoughts on chalkify vs formality subtyping?
• lazy TAITs on the 15th?

I think

  • 8th -- subtyping/variance chapter review wg-traits#37
  • 15th -- lazy tait walk through wg-traits#36
  • 22nd -- formality subtyping rules wg-traits#39
  • 29nd -- chalkify roadmap planning wg-traits#32
uhh I meant +
I can cover the subtyping rules with @oli separately I think, and I feel like I'd like him there for chalkify roadmap planning
if he wants to be :)
he is nice and skeptical and I'm always like "This should take 2 weeks"
sounds good to me
that's a point I was going to bring up though: who wants to lead these
this plan lgtm
the first two kind of have docs already, right?
well lazy tait is obvlsy me I guess XD
chalkify roadmap I can cover
yeah, the first is just "read this PR, let's discuss"
Doesn't so much need someone to lead
I was figuring lazy tait, @oli, would take the form of reviewing the rustc-dev-guide PR (which implies you ought to add to it, if it's not complete, I kind of forget)
I might reach out to the PR author and see if they would be interested in joining
ok, i'll prepare wg-traits#39
great

• 8th -- subtyping/variance chapter review wg-traits#37 -- review PR
  • 15th -- lazy tait walk through wg-traits#36 -- @oli to prep rustc-dev-guide PR
  • 22nd -- formality subtyping rules wg-traits#39 -- @nikomatsakis to prep a doc
  • 29nd -- chalkify roadmap planning wg-traits#32 -- @Jack Huey to prep a doc
I will reach out to the PR author for the subtyping chapter. If they can make it to a separate date but not next week, maybe we shuffle, maybe not
Okay, any other announcements?
I'll edit the calendar events
I can post a comment on the PRs
issues*
Okay, if nobody has anything else...
@rustbot end-meeting
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
ah there we go
Thanks everyone for joining :)
thanks y'all
Thanks!
About NLL I opened a thread in the wg-nll group for the nll diagnostics issue, there are 4 and I think they all can be closed. Someone with authority just need to go over them :pray:
It would be really great to finally stabilize NLL and remove the migration mode once and for<'all>
Hey! I'm the author of the subtyping PR. Where would I find the link to join the discussion on Friday?
There will be a thread in this stream
Like this one
Ok thanks, I'll keep an eye out for that
